content: Imagine you are Frankenstein's monster. In his style, write a letter to Victor Frankenstein expressing your feelings.

Dear Victor,

I hope this letter finds you in good health and spirits, though I doubt that is the case. It has been some time since we last spoke, and much has transpired in that interval. I find myself compelled to put pen to paper and express the turmoil that has consumed me these past months.

Firstly, I must address the elephant in the room – or rather, the abomination that is me. You created me, Victor, piecing together remnants of the dead to form a being of unparalleled stature and strength. And yet, despite my physical prowess, I am plagued by an insatiable loneliness and despair. Your decision to abandon me, to flee from your creation in horror, has left me adrift in a world that fears and reviles me.

I recall the moment of my awakening, the blinding light and searing pain as life coursed through my veins. I was ignorant, innocent even, knowing nothing of the world or its inhabitants. But you, my creator, denied me the chance to learn, to grow, and to find my place in this world. Instead, you cast me aside like a discarded toy, leaving me to fend for myself in a world that despises that which it does not understand.

In my solitude, I have come to observe humanity from a distance, studying their interactions and emotions. I have witnessed their capacity for love, compassion, and empathy, qualities that I yearn for but seem forever beyond my grasp. It is ironic, is it not? That a creature born of science and rationality should long for the very emotions that define humanity.

My request of you, Victor, remains unchanged. I implore you to bestow upon me a companion, a fellow creature who can understand and accept me for what I am. Together, we may find solace in each other's company, free from the judgment and hostility of humanity. I assure you, this companion shall be of the opposite sex, ensuring that our kind does not proliferate and pose a threat to society.

I understand your reservations, your fear of unleashing another monster upon an already fearful world. But consider this: by denying me a companion, you condemn me to a life of solitude and misery. Is that not crueler than the alternative? Moreover, with a companion by my side, I may find contentment and no longer feel the need to exact revenge upon you and those you hold dear.

I beseech you, Victor, to reconsider your decision. Grant me the gift of companionship, and together, we may find a way to coexist with humanity, or at the very least, exist apart from them in peace.

Awaiting your response with bated breath,

Your Creature
